brief_description of the content in the: The source URL provides information about a JetBrains Inspectopedia rule that reports incorrect 'mode' configuration in the @DirtiesContext annotation in Spring Testing.
generated_rule_explanation from GPT-4: The rule 'invalid-dirtiescontext-mode-configuration' checks all classes in the project. If a class has the @DirtiesContext annotation, it retrieves the 'mode' attribute of the annotation. It then asserts that the 'mode' attribute is one of the valid values: 'AFTER_EACH_TEST_METHOD', 'AFTER_CLASS', 'BEFORE_EACH_TEST_METHOD', or 'BEFORE_CLASS'. If the 'mode' attribute is not one of these values, it reports an error message indicating the invalid mode configuration in the @DirtiesContext annotation for the class.
PRE_model_validation: The rule is syntactically correct and uses only the built-in functions. It follows the RSL syntax and uses the functions getClasses, hasAnnotation, getAnnoAttr, and getFQN. The rule checks for the @DirtiesContext annotation in all classes and validates the 'mode' attribute of the annotation.
3rd-party most relevant URLs and summary:
1. URL: https://www.baeldung.com/spring-dirtiescontext
Summary: This page provides a detailed explanation of the @DirtiesContext annotation in Spring Testing. It explains the different modes that can be configured in the 'mode' attribute of the annotation.

2. URL: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/48714116/what-is-the-use-of-dirtiescontext-in-spring
Summary: This StackOverflow thread discusses the use of the @DirtiesContext annotation in Spring Testing. It also mentions the 'mode' attribute and its possible values.
